page.title: 08HISTORY IN HALLATON TODAY 2
page.content: Hallaton was one of the most important towns in Leicestershire. Its prosperity is reflected in the size and imposing nature of the church which dates from Norman times. Many ancient houses are still standing, and over 10% of the 130 or so houses are thatched. For example the Bewicke Arms and cottages round the Cross are over 300 years old, and in Hunts Lane there are houses of Cruck construction with the original wattle and daub in places. One other converted house still has its original mud walls on two sides. In Churchgate there are two cottages owned by the Church which were originally three, bought in 1747 for poor ladies of the village and still used today for that purpose. Hallaton Charity cottages were built in 1842 and the Stenning cottages in 1926.
